item.title: Differences
item.description: The Monto Version 3 protocol differs from Version 2 in several ways. HTTP/2 instead of ZeroMQ ZeroMQ requires FFI, which is difficult in some editors and requires an additional dependency in all. For example, to implement monto-mode, a Monto major mode for emacs, the author needed to depend on elisp-ffi, a package that provides FFI for Emacs by spawning a subprocess and communicating with a custom protocol over pipes. Needless to say, this is horrible and inefficient.

item.title: Monto Version 3 Specification, Draft 1
item.description: Abstract This specification describes an improved iteration of the Monto protocol for Disintegrated Development Environments ([MONTO]) . These improvements allow for simpler implementations for Clients. They also make it feasible to have multiple Clients sharing a single Service, and for Services to be operated over the Internet (rather than on the local network or on a single machine). 1. Conventions and Terminology The key words “MUST”, “MUST NOT”, “REQUIRED”, “SHALL”, “SHALL NOT”, “SHOULD”, “SHOULD NOT”, “RECOMMENDED”, “MAY”, and “OPTIONAL” in this document are to be interpreted as described in RFC 2119.

item.title: Overview, Justifications, and FAQs
item.description: Note: This document has some overlap with the Differences document; read that too. Overview of Monto 3 Monto 3 is split into two “subprotocols,” the Client Protocol and the Service Protocol. This is done so that changes and extensions can be made to each one individually. For example, adding multi-user caching for services to the specification requires no differences in the Client Protocol, so it does not require bumping the Client Protocol version number.
